verb.description: Examine (something) in order to determine its accuracy, quality, or condition, or to detect the presence of something.
examples: customs officers have the right to check all luggage
a simple blood test to check for anemia

verb.description: Stop or slow down the progress of (something undesirable)
examples: efforts were made to check the disease

verb.description: (of a passenger) consign (baggage) to the care of the transport provider with whom they are traveling.
examples: I checked my bag and got my boarding pass

verb.description: Mark or click on (a box) in order to select a particular option on a form, questionnaire, etc.
examples: users who want privacy should check the box that prevents your files from being shared

verb.description: Move a piece or pawn so that (the opposing king) is under attack.
(in poker) choose not to make a bet when called upon, allowing the action to move to another player.
(of a hound) pause to make sure of or regain a scent.

noun.description: An examination to test or ascertain accuracy, quality, or satisfactory condition.
examples: a campaign calling for regular checks on gas appliances

noun.description: A stopping or slowing of progress.
examples: there was no check to the expansion of the market

noun.description: A move by which a piece or pawn directly attacks the opponent's king. If the defending player cannot counter the attack, the king is checkmated.
A written order to a bank to pay a stated sum from the drawer's account.
examples: he was awarded a check for $1,000

noun.description: A token of identification for left luggage.
A counter used as a stake in a gambling game.
A part of a piano that catches the hammer and prevents it from retouching the strings.
A crack or flaw in timber.

exclamation.description: Used by a chess player to announce that the opponent's king has been placed in check.

adjective.description: Having a pattern of small squares.

phrases: a way of keeping inflation in check
But she was going to have to keep her temper in check if she was going to make the best of this situation.
Jim felt his rage surfacing and held it in check just enough to maintain control.
Competition from imported goods may keep inflation in check, some economists say.
Fiber also keeps blood insulin levels in check, which is a big factor in controlling body fat.
you must check in at least one hour before take-off
And since check-out time is usually around noon, the tour agencies can actually save a day's room rate by checking them in after noontime.
We stopped at the main desk of the dingy motel and waited while Jimmy registered and checked us in.
After checking us in, he motions for me to follow him.
The guys took care of checking us in while I said goodbye to my aunt.
origin: Late Middle English: probably from chequer (sense 1 of the noun).
